episode.title: The Times, They are a-Changin'
episode.description: Pilot: Lessons Learned at EDUCAUSE 2013, Episode 1

events.title: ETV The Times, They Are a Changin'

events.annotation: There are a lot of changes happening in the world of higher education, which quite obviously impact educational technology and where it's appropriate.

events.title: A Brief History of Distance Education
The Effect on the Traditional Classroom

events.annotation: We had the opportunity to talk to Scott Jaschik and Doug Lederman, co-editors of Inside Higher Ed.
ADVANCES IN EDUCATION TECHNOLOGY
And in this discussion, we were able to cover online education and distance education. It's not new; it's happened for decades.
It's not new...
We were able to talk about recent developments with massive open online courses, or MOOCs, and how those change the conversation.
We talked about how the traditional classroom is also getting affected by technology.  And then finally, we also talked about: What are the issues that get raised by the usage of technology?
What are the issues that get raised?
So Michael, from listening to this, what did you hear or what struck you?
NEW CONVERSATIONS TO INITIATE CHANGE
Well, what I heard was that there are a lot of conversations on campuses that need to be happening about these changes that aren't yet happening.
There are questions about goals, access, affordability, cost, quality.  There are questions about resource challenges and labor issues.
Goals, access, affordability, cost, quality

And because these new changes are coming up in conversation based on hype and campuses are in a reactive mode, we're not seeing the kind of discussion that needs to happen in order for institutions to decide how they can move forward together to solve real educational problems.
We're not seeing the kind of discussion that needs to happen..."
We're hoping to catalyze some of those conversations here. So with that, let's go to Phil's conversation with Scott and Doug.
We're here with Scott Jaschik and Doug Lederman. They are both co-editors of Inside Higher Ed, which is a publication that covers as a news source for all higher education.
So, I think it's a great opportunity to talk to you guys today.  Thank you for coming.
Thank you.
Our pleasure.
To get started, online education in particular and even distance education, there's nothing new right there.  This has been going on for a while.
So, how did we get to the point we're at within higher education?  Why should schools care about this?
Why should schools care?
You mean with distance education?  We've had distance education for a long time.

events.title: History of University of Maryland University College (UMUC)
events.description: Official history page on the UMUC website

events.annotation: So, after World War II, the GI's stay in Germany and then later in Korea, institutions like University of Maryland University College created correspondence programs supplemented by people being over there.

You have places like City University of New York, for decades, has been doing CUNY TV, offering courses on television.  So, all kinds of long-standing experiments and actual programs without people being physically on campus.

events.title: CUNY TV
events.description: Wikipedia page giving overview of CUNY TV, including its history

events.annotation: THE BEGINNING OF ONLINE EDUCATION
Now, in the '90s and then taking off in 2000 and on, you had colleges using online education to offer courses—some for credit, some for not—to students all over.

events.title: Virtual Universities c. 1998
events.description: This site gives one of the earliest combined listing of virtual universities and various online degree programs

events.title: Story of University of Phoenix
events.description: Public radio story on history of University of Phoenix and motivations of its founder John Sperling

events.annotation: And what's different, sort of starting in the '90s and now we're in different periods of this; we had a bunch of entrepreneurial institutions, for-profits like the University of Phoenix.
And also, very entrepreneurial traditional colleges, like say Regis College or St. Leo's, that created programs and were educating many more students off campus than on campus.

events.title: St Leo Online
events.description: St Leo website for its online programs

events.title: Regis University Online
events.description: Regis University website for its online programs

events.title: Penn State World Campus
events.description: Wikipedia page on Penn State World Campus, also known as Penn State Online

events.annotation: In the public sector—places like Penn State, places like University of Maryland University College—educating many more students online than in person.
TRANSFORMING THE ONLINE EDUCATION MARKET
So, this has been going on for a long time.  What we're seeing now is a different stage.

events.title: Coursera Doubles University Partners
events.description: Article from summer 2012 at Inside Higher Ed describing new institutional partner signups

events.title: Online Ed: More than MOOCs
events.description: Webinar provided by Inside Higher Ed giving overview of online education based on curation of IHE articles and surveys

events.title: edX Airways
events.description: IHE essay: Elite universities won't upend online learning market

events.annotation: The original players—generally not the elite institutions—now with MOOCs, you have a different set of institutions saying, "We want to be part of this market and to define the market."
We want to be part of this market and to define the market.
What I see is the desire to use technology, mostly because of the financial pressures that institutions are under and that states are under; desire to use technology to try to bend the cost curve.
...the desire to use technology to bend the cost curve
There's a great desire to increase the number of people with college credentials of some sort.
President Obama and a slew of foundations and others are trying to push this "completion agenda," as we call it.

events.title: Obama Admin Higher Ed Positions
events.description: Official White House website describing the Obama administration priorities and positions for higher ed

events.title: The Completion Cacophony
events.description: IHE article on the need for an increase in completion with meaningful credentials from US colleges

events.annotation: ...trying to push this Completion Agenda

And there's a sense that technology can be part of the answer in doing that because you can't educate a whole lot more people with flat or even decreasing funds. There's a sense that the technology makes possible certain kinds of education that wasn't possible before.
Let's actually jump a little bit more into the MOOC subject because, as we are saying it, clearly MOOCs did not begin online education.

events.title: Educational Technology in Online Education Models
events.description: Scott, Doug, and Phil dig into the question of how online education fits with different sectors of the education markets

events.title: The Online Pecking Order
events.description: IHE article discussing how conventional online universities are considering strategic responses to MOOCs

events.annotation: MOOCs did not begin online education
Even today, they are only one of the models that are out there.  But it's important, particularly in terms of what's being viewed by the public and some of the key stakeholders.
Why have MOOCs brought new schools into the discussion about online education and why should campus leaders actually care about MOOCs and what they might be able to do?
Why have MOOCs brought new schools into the discussion about online education?
VARIOUS APPLICATIONS OF MOOCS
Let's say you're a public university.  For most public universities right now, they have classes that are larger than they would like, and many of them have waiting lists to get into class.

events.title: Essay on California MOOC Bill
events.description: Essay from Phil Hill and Dean Flores in Inside Higher Ed about the 'demise' of SB520, the bill seeking third-party online courses for the three public systems in California

events.annotation: So, theoretically you could use MOOCs if you're happy with the quality of instruction, combined with some sort of on-campus instruction to teach a lot of people you don't have room for or instructors to teach.
Combined with On-Campus Instruction

events.title: 7 Things You Should Know about Flipped Classrooms
events.description: Document by EDUCAUSE that summarizes the key issues that campus leaders should know about flipped classrooms

events.annotation: VARIOUS APPLICATIONS OF MOOCS

events.title: U Texas CTL: What is the Flipped Classroom?
events.description: Information page from Center for Teaching & Learning at the University of Texas Austin describing basic concept of flipped classroom

events.annotation: There's also a lot of excitement about the concept of the flipped classroom, where lectures are replaced by online content delivery and are using the classroom time in different ways.

events.title: Still in Favor of the Flip
events.description: IHE article: despite new studies, flipping the classroom still enjoys widespread support

events.annotation: Flipped Classroom: Replacing the Lecture
But a lot of this, you have to look at the details.  If the motivation is just to save money and do it in the least expensive way possible, well then you just broadcast MOOCs.

events.title: Online and Productivity, pt 1
events.description: Tony Bates writes a summary for WCET of his series of articles on productivity and online learning, part 1

events.title: Online and Productivity, pt 2
events.description: Tony Bates writes a summary for WCET of his series of articles on productivity and online learning, part 2

events.annotation: UNDERSTANDING IMPACT ON STUDENT EXPERIENCE

Then, the real question is about the student experience.  Doing distance ed well—generally, this is pre-MOOC and post-MOOC—good distance education isn't cheap because, in good distance education, there actually may well be student faculty interaction, student discussion, somebody actually grading papers.
Good distance education isn't cheap
None of those things have to go away in online education.  But if you have a MOOC teaching 200,000 students, they may go away.
If you notice, the elite institutions are offering the courses but they are not making really any movement at all toward offering credit for those courses on their own campuses.

events.title: ACE recommends 5 MOOCs For Credit
events.description: Article from 2013 in Inside Higher Ed about the American  Council on Education (ACE) recommending that schools award credit for 5 MOOCs provided by Coursera and Udacity

events.title: Credit-for-MOOCs Effort Hits a Snag
events.description: Article from 2014 in the Chronicle about delays in the ACE pilot awarding credit for MOOCs, due to lack of institutional participation

events.annotation: Those institutions say that they are using the MOOCs, or that they are experimenting with MOOCs, to try to inform, to understand how technology can enhance the classroom experience.

And part of the reason there's some resentment against the elites, because if you're a faculty member out at one of those mid-level publics, you're a little worried that you're administrators are going to tell you, are going to replace you, honestly, with the MOOCs, with online courses.

events.title: SJSU Faculty Pushes Back Against edX
events.description: Article in Inside Higher Ed about the San Jose State University (SJSU) Philosophy Department writing an open letter to Harvard professor Michael Sandel regarding the use of his edX course

events.title: Political Philosophy
events.description: Michael Feldstein analysis of the SJSU letter at e-Literate blog

events.annotation: And so, there's real, different motivations for why the institutions are getting into it in terms of the offering of the MOOCs. But also, there's real questions about how institutions are going to use them.
There's real, different motivations
MERGING EDUCATION TECHNOLOGY AND THE TRADITIONAL CLASSROOM
So, let's talk a little bit about the traditional classroom and how it's getting affected.  What's driving the increased usage of educational technology in a traditional face-to-face classroom?

events.title: MOOCs from the Institutional Perspective
events.description: Doug, Scott, and Phil explore the potential institutional impact of MOOCs in more detail

events.annotation: What's driving the increased usage of educational technology in a traditional face-to-face classroom?
Well, you have drivers from students and from faculty.  From students, you have the reality that they're walking into class with multiple devices and are going to use them in various ways.

events.title: BYOD AND CONSUMERIZATION OF IT IN HIGHER EDUCATION
events.description: Summary document at EDUCAUSE giving an overview of the consumerization of IT and bring your own device (BYOD) trend, which they describe as bring your own everything (BYOE)

events.annotation: Whether they are opening their laptop and following course materials or on Facebook is a subject of much debate.  But the fact is, they are online all the time.

So, the question is: How do you use that productively?  On the educational side, basic tasks like attendance, grading, communication with students—all online because that's the only way you would reach them.
How do you use that productively?
You can't call them on their landline.

events.title: Purdue Course Signals Wins Award
events.description: Purdue press release about an award for their Course Signals initiative providing early alert capabilities for select courses at the university

events.title: Purdue Course Signals Data Issue Explainer
events.description: e-Literate guest blogger Mike Caufield explains the issues that have arisen around whether Course Signals improves retention

events.annotation: TAKING ADVANTAGE OF TECHNOLOGY

events.title: Mixed Signals
events.description: IHE article: Researchers cast doubt about early-warning systems' ability to effect student retention

events.annotation: But more important, I think, is the use of technology, say, for early warning systems.  People can tell which students are doing the work, which students are turning in assignments, how they are doing on certain topics.
So, professors can know, "Phil is really missing this concept or not doing his work," and can reach out.

With adaptive learning, individual exercises can point from task to task which subjects a student has mastered, which subjects a student hasn't.  So, it really is transforming the educational experience in institutions with in-person students and faculty.

events.title: The New Intelligence
events.description: IHE article: Arizona State and Knewton's grand experiment in adaptive learning

events.annotation: Obviously, technology is not the only way to deal with the economic challenges that you're talking about—serving more students with the reduced budgets. We've seen very large class sizes just happening on their own.
Technology is not the only way to deal with the economic challenges..."
Does educational technology play a role there, sort of after the fact, of enabling or taking these large lectures and making them either more practical or more effective; or how do they affect that?

Well, that's the thing.  You certainly see things like the use of clickers and that's the thing.  If you define technology broadly, there are lots of ways that technology can use, can sort of shape the classroom and make it work better.
ROLE OF TECHNOLOGY IN ENABLING & MONITORING LARGE LECTURES

I was just at a meeting where somebody made the old joke about how distance education starts in the fourth row in the classroom. So, there are ways that technology can improve the face-to-face classroom.

There are other ways where it can be an alternative to it. But I think we are seeing a lot of interest in trying to see how technology can improve the outcomes and the performance of students in the classroom.
At the same time, the need for people hasn't gone away.

events.title: Pressure on the Provosts: 2014 Survey of Chief Academic Officers
events.description: The most recent of an annual survey by Inside Higher Ed and Gallup of the attitudes and perceptions of Chief Academic Officers

events.title: Mixed Grades: A Survey of Provosts
events.description: Description of the findings of an IHE survey of provosts and chief academic officers at American colleges and universities

events.annotation: The need for people hasn't gone away

And one of the interesting phenomenon that we've written about and we've found out about in our surveys of campus leaders is that a lot of campuses say they are doing tons of surveys: using technology to monitor what students are learning, which courses they take, which patterns are working, and so forth.
Then, you ask them, "Are you confident you're using that information in a good way?" They don't have very much confidence in that.
Are you confident you're using that information in a good way?

And that's not a slam on the technology. The technology is actually, in many cases, providing information that either a provost, an academic advisor, or an individual faculty member can use to help students.
But if you don't train those people on how to use the information and give them the support and time to use that information, you may be compiling data points to nowhere.
TAKING ADVANTAGE OF THE INFORMATION
You ultimately need somebody to act on technology and, for instance, a lot of the tools involving students, particularly at risk students—they need academic advising from a person.

Technology can greatly increase the information available and there's a lot of evidence that it could lead to much better academic advising. But at the same time, we've seen this technology take off; we've seen a gutting of academic advising because of budget cuts at institutions that serve low-income students.

events.title: Some Thoughts on Academic Advising and Technology
events.description: The views of the President of the National Academic Advising Association (NACADA) on the role of technology in academic advising.

events.annotation: Technology can greatly increase the information available
Could lead to much better academic advising
So, it's not an either/or, but a both. And that's why I think sometimes people miss the point about what's really going on with technology and learning.
"It's not an either/or, but a BOTH"
Are we actually seeing new models of education by applying technology to a face-to-face classroom that might impact the quality of what's the student experience?
And I'm thinking, for example, a lot of the discussion around flipped classrooms or hybrid education.

So, if you have students looking at lectures or other digital material on their own time, and then coming into the classroom and discussing it and having the instructor be the explainer, be the guide, work with the students who aren't getting it—that's where you have the potential for technology to be the biggest advantage in my eyes.
And so, the thing is that will not happen if a governor announces, "We're going to use MOOCs to educate 20 percent more students without a penny more."
When they make those decisions, what Doug just talked about won't happen.
MOOC USE IN FLIPPED AND HYBRID MODELS

Now, the flip side is, we just wrote about a group of women's studies professors who looked at the MOOC model and didn't like it. So, they created what's sort of an anti-MOOC, but actually embraces a lot of MOOC teaching.

events.title: Feminist Anti-MOOC
events.description: Article in Inside Higher Ed on a groups of women professors who created a MOOC alternative based on more engaging interaction

events.annotation: They created sort of an anti-MOOC

They've got centralized videos that will be seen from students at 20 different campuses. But then, at each campus, a real live professor in a classroom with 20 or fewer students will be leading discussions, doing individual exercises.

Now, there will also be group discussion forums, so the students will be interacting with students who aren't on their campus. But ultimately, the students will be graded as part of accredited colleges.

Now, this model uses MOOC technology, changes the teaching experience, broadens these classes to involve students from all over the world actually, but isn't going to save anyone any money because they are paying tuition at the colleges that they're enrolled at.
Uses MOOC technology
Changes the teaching experience
Involve students from all over the world
But, won't save money

Now, there probably are, no doubt, ways to save money and improve the educational experience. Where we see a lot of the problems, I think, are just when people automatically assume certain savings are possible.
At the same time, you expect professors to do more.
Higher ed will be a lot better off if technology spreads through experimentation by the willing.

events.title: Premature Implementation, pt.1
events.description: Doug, Scott, and Phil discuss the dangers of trends like MOOCs and flipped classrooms being adopted without proper thought and care

events.title: Premature Implementation, pt. 2
events.description: Doug, Scott, and Phil continue to discuss the dangers of trends like MOOCs and flipped classrooms being adopted without proper thought and care

events.annotation: SPREAD BY THE WILLING

I mean, the elite institutions have been able to build coalitions of the willing, whereas institutions that are feeling more financial pressure have imposed technological solutions on their faculty members promising great things and not necessarily delivering.

And if this is allowed to spread by those who believe in it, and I guess the other thing our survey shows is that as faculty members get exposure to online learning, to technology, they become more supportive of it. Duh!
EXPANSION THROUGH EXPOSURE AND EXPERIMENTATION

events.title: Survey of Faculty Attitudes on Technology
events.description: IHE survey of faculty members about the quality of online learning

events.annotation: But that takes time and we're seeing that kind of experimentation.
I think higher ed's taken a little bit of a knock for never experimenting. That's just not true.
There’s a lot of experimentation going on.  But it isn't as fast as some policy makers and some foundations want it to be.

So, it sounds like a lot of the issues that get raised by the technological change don't just come from the technology, per se, or whatever the specific innovation, but even from the way it's implemented: if it's done without faculty buy-in or of it's just dropped in or if it leads to an assumption.
So, we have an opportunity to implement—and it could exacerbate certain issues or we could implement it a different way—that will actually address the underlying issues that we need to face.
Opportunity to implement
Certainly.
Thank you. I'd like to thank Scott Jaschik and Doug Lederman from Inside Higher Ed for a great discussion.

But now we'd like to turn to you. On your campus or within your context, which are the educational challenges that are the most important and the most appropriate to be addressed with educational technology?

events.title: Join the Discussion
events.description: On your campus or within your context, which are the educational challenges that are the most important and the most appropriate to be addressed with educational technology? What are the areas where it's the most risky and the least appropriate to use technology?

events.annotation: And likewise, what are the areas where it's the most risky and the least appropriate to use technology to address on your campus? We'd like to hear from you in the discussions that we are creating.
